brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine whether implementing a rehabilitation program can
      improve the post-operative time to pain free living after breast augmentation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  women who undergo endoscopic transaxillary subpectoral breast augmentation

          -  women above the age of 18 years

          -  women with a BMI 18-27

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  women who underwent previous breast reconstruction (cosmetic or therapeutic)

          -  women who underwent previous chest surgery

          -  women with previous chest trauma

          -  women who underwent previous shoulder/arm surgery

          -  women with previous shoulder/arm injury

          -  women who smoke

          -  women who are Immunocompromised

clinical_study.official_title: How Rehabilitation Affects the Time to Pain-free Living After Endoscopic Transaxillary Subpectoral Breast Augmentation

primary_outcome.measure: Time to return to baseline as measured on Visual Analogue Scale for pain
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, six months, and one year after surgery

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to return to bilateral shoulder baseline range of motion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, six months, and one year after surgery

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in psychosocial outcomes as measured by the BREAST-Q questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, six months, and one year after surgery

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Double Blind (Subject, Investigator), Primary Purpose: Supportive Care
